entry.title: Black Eagle Silver Certificates (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that between 1899 and 1923 the United States government issued 3,604,239,600 one-dollar Black Eagle Silver Certificates (example pictured)?

entry.title: J1407b (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that although J1407b eclipsed V1400 Centauri in 2007, nobody noticed for over three years?

entry.title: Amir Zakirov (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in order to attend breakdancing classes as a child, future Olympian Amir Zakirov had to give up eating lunch?

entry.title: The Book of Virtues (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that The Book of Virtues inspired PBS's first animated primetime series?

entry.title: cancelled over antisemitism allegations in Germany (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that one researcher found that nearly a third of the people cancelled over antisemitism allegations in Germany have been Jews?

entry.title: statue of Dirk Nowitzki (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that plans for a statue of Dirk Nowitzki to have three basketballs were scrapped?

entry.title: El Eternauta: segunda parte (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that during the writing of El Eternauta: segunda parte, Héctor Germán Oesterheld became victim of an enforced disappearance?

entry.title: Palestinian right of armed resistance (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that arguments in favor of a Palestinian right of armed resistance are often based on Article 1(4) of Protocol I to the Geneva Conventions?

entry.title: a magical inanimate dog (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a magical inanimate dog may have been a taxidermy dog, an automaton, or a metaphor?
